misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from two velocities and time instead of summing the even numbers among 5 integers as specified in the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can answer this question by writing a program that calculates average acceleration from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This question requires a program that reads exactly 5 integers from the user, identifies which of them are even using a condition like `n % 2 == 0`, sums only those even numbers, and prints the sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
Computation uses the acceleration formula `(v1 - v0) / t` instead of summing selected inputs.
Output message reports 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with a different exercise or insufficient attention to the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify exactly what inputs are needed (5 integers), what needs to be selected (only even numbers), and what final value is required (the sum of those even numbers). Then design your variables, loop, and condition around that description.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, types, formula, and output text) corresponds to an acceleration problem, not to summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: The code clearly implements an acceleration calculation with three double inputs and corresponding output text, not a sum of even numbers from 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration, which is an entirely different problem from the assignment objective of calculating the sum of 5 even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assigned task was to calculate average acceleration, or they submitted the wrong file for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required a program to read 5 integers, use a loop, check for even numbers using the modulo operator (%), and print the accumulated sum.
symptoms: Variables v0, v1, and t are used.
Calculation is the acceleration formula: (v1 - v0) / t.
Program reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs.
Output relates to acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt or submitting code written for a different exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully review the full assignment question ('Sum of Even Numbers [4 marks]') and ensure the submitted code directly addresses all requirements outlined in the prompt and rubric (reading 5 integers, using a loop, checking for even numbers, and accumulating the sum).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements a well-known formula for acceleration, which definitively confirms it does not address the required sum-of-even-numbers problem.

evidence.note: The prompt asks for acceleration inputs, contradicting the assignment requirement.
Wrong number (3) and type (double) of inputs read.

evidence.snippet: double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration
evidence.note: The calculation performed is for acceleration, not accumulation.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have completely misunderstood the assignment. The task requires reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, but the student wrote a program that computes acceleration from three floating-point inputs (v0, v1, t).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this assignment is about calculating average acceleration using the formula a = (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q1 asks to read 5 integers from the user and print the sum of only the even numbers. The expected output for input '3 8 2 7 4' is 'Sum of even numbers: 14'.
symptoms: Program reads 3 floating-point values instead of 5 integers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
Program computes acceleration instead of sum of evens
Output message is completely different from required format
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have submitted code for the wrong problem, possibly from a physics or different assignment about acceleration calculations.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Use a loop to process each one, (3) Check if each number is even using (n % 2 == 0), (4) Accumulate the sum of even numbers, (5) Print the result in the format 'Sum of even numbers: X'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no ambiguity here. The submission is solving a completely different problem. The rubric explicitly asks for 5 integers and summing even numbers, with sample input/output provided. The student's code reads 3 doubles and computes acceleration—there is no overlap in requirements.

evidence.note: Reading 3 double values instead of 5 integers as required by the rubric

evidence.snippet:
double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ;
        System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ;
evidence.note: Computing acceleration instead of sum of even numbers; output format is wrong
Class name 'AccelerationQ1' suggests this is code from a different assignment/topic

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (implemented a different problem)
misconceptions.description:
The student has implemented a physics acceleration calculator instead of the required 'sum of even numbers from 5 integers' program. The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t), computes acceleration, and prints it, rather than reading 5 integers, checking which are even, accumulating their sum, and printing that sum. This reflects a misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements rather than a small coding slip.

Rubric-based scoring and feedback:
- Reading 5 integers from input (1.0 pt): 0/1
  Feedback: The program reads 3 values (v0, v1, t) as doubles instead of 5 integers. It also prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.

- Loop structure to process inputs (1.0 pt): 0/1
  Feedback: There is no loop at all. The task requires processing 5 inputs, typically using a loop to read and handle each value.

- Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0) (1.0 pt): 0/1
  Feedback: No conditional logic checks for even numbers; the code performs a numerical formula for acceleration instead.

- Accumulating sum and printing result (1.0 pt): 0/1
  Feedback: The program computes a single acceleration value with a physics formula and prints it. It never computes or prints the sum of even numbers.

Overall feedback: Score = 0/4. The submitted program solves a different problem (average acceleration) and does not address the requirements of summing even numbers from 5 integers. Carefully re-read the question and ensure your program structure (inputs, loop, conditionals, and output) directly matches what is asked: read 5 integers, use a loop, test each with n % 2 == 0, accumulate a running sum for even numbers only, and print that sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving any physics-related numeric problem (here, computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) is appropriate for this question, or they confused this question with a different assignment about acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must specifically follow the stated requirements: read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process all 5 inputs, use a conditional (like n % 2 == 0) to identify even numbers, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: <sum>'. Any other computation (such as physics formulas) does not satisfy the problem.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Uses three double variables (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.
No loop is used to handle multiple inputs.
No modulo operation or conditional check for even numbers appears in the code.
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
Core computation is (v1 - v0) / t rather than summing selected inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or failure to align the implemented program with the exact problem specification. The student may have copied or reused code from an acceleration example without adapting it to this task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Set aside the acceleration example and start from the problem statement: 1) Prompt the user with 'Enter 5 integers:'. 2) Use a loop (for or while) that runs 5 times. 3) Inside the loop, read an int each time. 4) Use if (n % 2 == 0) to check if the number is even. 5) Maintain an int sum initialized to 0 and, when the number is even, add it to sum. 6) After the loop, print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by sum. Always ensure your program’s variables, prompts, and output text match the question’s description.
related_concepts: Conditionals and modulo operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every visible part of the program (prompt text, variable names, arithmetic formula, and output) corresponds to a standard acceleration example and not to the described 'sum of even numbers' task; there is no partial attempt at the required logic.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an acceleration calculator (v0, v1, t, and (v1 - v0) / t) and prints 'The average acceleration is ...', with no loop, no even-number check, and no summation of 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) and did not address any part of the required task (calculating the sum of 5 even numbers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may have confused this assignment with another or failed to read the prompt, believing they were submitting a solution for a physics calculation (acceleration) problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones, utilizing a loop, conditional logic, and an accumulator.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t)
Reads only 3 inputs (v0, v1, t)
Reads floating-point numbers (doubles) instead of integers
No loop structure present
No conditional check for even numbers (modulo operator missing)
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow the instructions for the assigned problem (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and restart the implementation of 'Sum of Even Numbers'. Focus on using a loop to get 5 inputs, and an 'if' statement with the modulus operator (%) to check for evenness (n % 2 == 0).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code clearly solves a different problem (calculating acceleration) using variables v0, v1, and t, confirming a complete misunderstanding or misfiling of the assignment.

evidence.note: The entire main method is dedicated to calculating acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage for Input
misconceptions.description: The assignment required reading 5 integers, but the student used `nextDouble()` to read floating-point numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that `double` is the appropriate type for reading generic numerical input, or they conflated the input requirements because they were solving an equation that typically uses real numbers (acceleration).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To read integers, one should use the `nextInt()` method of the Scanner class and store the results in `int` variables. While `nextDouble()` might work if integer inputs are provided, it is incorrect per the assignment specification and task context.
symptoms: Use of `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`
Variables defined as `double` instead of `int`
misconceptions.root_cause: The primary error is misinterpreting the problem; however, even for the acceleration problem, the choice of `double` highlights a potential lack of precision regarding data type requirements if integers were expected.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure variables are declared as `int` and input is read using `input.nextInt()` when processing integer inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The assignment explicitly requires reading integers (implicit in 'Sum of Even Numbers'). The student reads doubles using nextDouble.

evidence.note: Reads a double, but the task requires reading integers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Problem Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student has misread or misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely. Instead of solving the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem, the student wrote a program to calculate acceleration from velocity and time inputs. This demonstrates a critical failure to understand the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to calculate average acceleration given two velocities and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, identifying which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), summing only the even numbers, and printing the result. The expected output format is 'Sum of even numbers: 14' (not acceleration calculations).
symptoms: Program reads only 3 inputs instead of 5
Reads double values instead of integers
No loop structure present
No even/odd checking logic
No sum accumulation
Output calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Input prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student failed to carefully read or understand the problem statement. The submitted code is for a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. The task is NOT about acceleration. Write a program that: (1) reads 5 integers in a loop, (2) checks if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulates the sum of even numbers only, (4) prints the result in format 'Sum of even numbers: X'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a completely different problem with zero overlap with the required solution. Variable names (v0, v1, t), input count (3 vs 5), logic (acceleration formula vs even sum), and output format are all misaligned with Q1 requirements.

evidence.note: Program reads 3 double values (v0, v1, t) when the assignment requires 5 integers. The prompt text confirms this is for a different problem.

evidence.snippet:
double a = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ;

System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + a ) ;
evidence.note: Program calculates acceleration using physics formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers. Output format is also wrong.
Entire program structure solves an acceleration problem. No loop for processing 5 integers, no conditional for checking even numbers, no accumulator for summing.
